job_title: Logistics Manager in Des Moines, IA
pros: I have worked for several international Non-Governmental Organizations including the United Nations. The outstanding values and competencies that Action Against Hunger (AAH) has are the value for integrity, professionalism and team work. The culture of the organization, including impartiality, fairness, honesty and truthfulness in daily activities and behavior, will encourage anyone to give in your very best at work. This is an place where workers don't abuse power or authority and prompt action is taken in case of unprofessional or unethical behavior. Staff show pride in work and achievement and demonstrate professional competencies and mastery of their professions. If ever you want to work in an environment where all staff collaborate with each other to achieve organizational goals by genuinely valuing other ideas and expertise, the AAH is the right place to work. With AAH, I learned more of taking ownership for all responsibilities and honoring commitments. I was trained to see things from clients' point of view and to maintain productive partnership with clients by gaining their trust and respect. Action Against Hunger is one among many organizations that encourages and support staff who are committed to continuous learning.
cons: Salary and compensation structures need to be revisited. This is both for national and international staff.

pros: There's room for career growth
cons: Lack of proper training for new staff

review_title: Incompetent and over-paid management at country level
pros: True humanitarians working in the field with a high number of local staff (better than most INGOs for inclusion of locals)
cons: The main purpose of this review is to voice frustration (and perhaps a systemic problem I see in development work) in the huge disparity between what expat staff are paid - grossly high salaries/packages - to local staff - who are undoubtedly doing the majority of the work. Even expats in the country taking local contracts are doing - or responsible for, in my experience, so much more actual work day to day than senior management at country director or DCD level. It is a gross inequality, perpetuating a colonialist mindset and funneling more money to those who already have it. It is truly sad to see and I hope that this organization will take a closer look at what senior management in-country is accountable for (very little, in my experience) and if their pay really needs to be 10x higher than a local.

review_title: Filed work is better than working at NY Head Quarters
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great international culture, very hard working and dedicated staff. Some people have been working with the organization for many years. It has a very good reputation in Europe and in the Humanitarian field. It gives chances to people that other they will not get in other places.
cons:
The organization has grown too fast in a very short time and it was not ready for it. It seems a bit lost and unprepared.
There is a very unhealthy working environment, people are drained and not motivated. Need for improvement in management, long working stressful days and very poor recognition of employees. Very high turn over for such small organization. No employee support from HR or Management. It is a non for profit but certain things are managed corporate, very corporate.

review_title: Great mission and colleagues despite terrible senior management.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Great mission.

Awesome work being done in the the countries of operation. 

Technical leadership in the humanitarian sector for nutrition programs.

Wonderful colleagues.
cons:
Senior management is unprofessional and often does not seem to know what they (or their staff) does.  This is across departments and reflects overall poor hiring decisions/ practices from the top. 

A lot of time in staff meetings is spent talking about values that are not practiced in the NY HQ.

Leadership has been trying to establish a new vision for the organizations future for more then a year now, but still are unable to articulate how the vision will be achieved to employees.

Job security is low as it is completely unclear if certain functions will be prioritized with the new vision and if jobs will be kept in NY .

Turnover is high - which is relatively common in the humanitarian sector- however, Action Against Hunger USA is much worse then I have seen else where in this regard.

I question if technical leadership in nutrition within the sector can be maintained under current leadership.

pros: The Organization has a good reputation within the NGO field. Globally, they are a financially sound organization, though projects are tied to funding.  A great purpose, but you can find a lot of great of organizations in this field and they'll treat you, and local staff,  much better. You'll learn to be very resourceful as approval processes for projects, spending, and other assets is glacial.
cons: Pay is poor and the possibility for upward mobility is limited. This is a French organization and if you aren't French, your upward limit is probably the position you were hired for.  Like many NGOs, they only pay lip service to equality and women's health, much less maternity leave simply isn't there. Pay is often late, incorrect, or both for mid to low level staff. Staff in upper level positions are paid very well and have excellent job security while the rest is a turn-and-burn approach to staffing.

pros:
I joined Action Against Hunger International more than 5 years ago having worked previously in the private sector and started of at the entry level with basic humanitarian work experience but with a specific vision in mind. Like everyone else, I wanted to advance in my career and could only achieve that by working for an organization that offered growth and development opportunities. Action Against Hunger International has  offered me a chance to not only bring out the best in me but also stretched me to be even better and i have had a chance of working with the most amazing team members.  The organization offers effective career advancement plan that include expanding employees' skills sets, giving us additional and more challenging responsibilities that results to staff utilising their full potential, acknowledging accomplishments through promotions and offering a tailored career advancement plan for each employee that aligns with our professional goals through the 10 minutes conversations with our line manager and Proffessional Development Plan .


I am happy with the person I have become today thanks to Action Against Hunger!
cons: I have nothing to say

review_title: Does not treat employees in the field well
pros: Excellent technical knowledge and strong expertise in fighting malnutrition. Engaged and motivated coworkers eager to contribue to the NGOs mission.
cons: Treats employees working in the field very poorly and as disposable assets. Low pay compared to education and required skill level. Poor health care coverage including for ailments acquired while on mission in the field. Fails to live up to its ideals in not providing support for returned volunteers and employees. Seems to have a policy of not renewing the contract of employees who fall ill on mission or after return, causing them to lose health insurance coverge. Fellow humanitarians, please be careful - it can be very hard to afford thousands of dollars in medical bills following a mission with ACF when the health coverage expires. It is sad to work on nutrition and health projects abroad and then to return home only to find that your own care is not a priority for the organisation that you worked so hard for.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Someone needs to rescue this organization
cons:
The CEO is making huge strategic and operational changes just to try to make it look like he is a leader.  He has no idea what the eventual impact will be.  Massive change based on a suspicion. No substance.

He spins his Board into thinking he knows what he is doing.

A real CEO is needed.  This one is a sham.

Other leaders are minimally competent.

Low salaries and everyone does multiple jobs.

Favortism.

Lip service to values.

Enormous exodus after numerous attempts to convey concerns - groups wrote letters to Management expressing lack of confidence.

Efforts by Management to address issues have entirely missed the point.

A CEO with a huge ego and big salary spends most of his time at home.  He seems to think no one notices he barely works or gets anything done. Everyone notices.  Except the people he reports to - the Board.

So unfortunate.  Millions of people in needs and dollars spent going to waste.

pros: Very motivated colleagues.  The organization is composed of true humanitarians.  The organization has a focused strategy in nutrition. Its a good way to cut your teeth in humanitarian aid.  This organization truly saves lives and has a meaningful impact on the most vulnerable.
cons: Salary is low compared to other organizations. Also, the HR process for recruitment and support during the mission is lacking for U.S. contracts.  For example, one expat staff had to pay their own emergency medical evacuation due to HR mistake and then seek compensation after.   Needless to say emergency medical evac. is something that is 100% covered under expat health insurance.

review_title: Senior Management is ruining this place
pros: Dedicated staff who do everything to fulfill the mission and assist colleagues in country offices. Work life balance can be good if you try to make it that way. Good time off compared to other US companies.
cons: Super toxic work environment. Senior management ream consistently make terrible decisions - either on the direction of the organization or on the hiring of new staff. HR department does not address HR complaints in any real way and lets people who do unprofessional things to their employees get away with it - constantly. Senior management lets incompetent staff keep their jobs for way too long which leads to the organization to become in a very bad shape, both financially and in morale. Also the pay is only good if you're on the associate director level, they pay everyone below that very very badly, way under market rate. Senior management over the last 5 years has run this once thriving ACF office into the ground.

pros: Constant on the job trainings will be provided to you, the opportunity to learn and grow is available. They have a very effective performance management system which allows for you to have a minimum of a 10 minute conversation with you supervisor on your challenges, your accomplishment and what you can do to improve your self . I find these very motivating
cons: A little more can be done to improve upon staff welfare especially for those in the deep field areas, things like access to Internet for more than the current duration will be appreciated and go far in promoting staff motivation

review_title: Strong development and knowledge generation organisation with a focus on leadership
pros: Programmatically focused organisation; well respected within the sector; high level of autonomy depending on the specific pool; improved focus on leadership recently; good internal mobility for national staff to expat positions
cons: Training opportunities limited to internal workshops; support sometimes limited but this depends on the specific pool; not as quick at humanitarian work; salary on the lower to medium side

review_title: Be The Change You Want To Be
job_title: Human Resources Generalist in New York, NY
pros:
A place where everyone knows your name. 
Great benefits package (and not because I'm in charge of benefits) but more to come.
Great people that really care about our beneficiaries and what the bottom line is for the work that we do.
Flex time.
Summer Fridays (4 SF).
Work/life balance.
cons:
Changing dinamic, training needs to be address.
Culture needs to improve from within

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great mission saving the lives of malnourished children and helping/empowering communities in need around the word. Nice work environment. The team in HQ-NY has a lot of enthusiasm and is very committed. The organization has good benefits and pays fair salaries.
cons: Workload can be heavy especially for those providing support to the field programs.

pros: I’ve been working for Action Against Hunger for a couple of years now and I’ve developed strong trust in working with the organization. It has also created me a great opportunity and environment to put my professional contribution to best level to people in need of my support. I’m to a great extent inspired by and committed to the organization’s vision, mission and a charter.  Action Aganst Hunger    is an ideal organization for professional development as well.
cons: Nothing major to mention here

review_title: Not a great place to work!
pros: The only pro I can think of for working at Action Against Hunger are some of the colleagues you build a relationship with.
cons: One of the major cons of Action Against Hunger is how little management values the employees. I'm not even sure if they know the work that is being done. There is a lack of transparency, which ironically happens to be one of the organizations "core values." It seems the only way to move up in the organization is if you suck up to the right people.

pros: Our organization carry everyone along in her day to day activities most especially in terms of internal communication couples with concern for  our safety. Also, there is opportunity for growth within our organization.
cons: Some people sees their position as a means to determine the future of those they are line managing so if you have a personal (informal) issue with them, it turns out to be detrimental on your professional career.

review_title: Great progress with compensation and remuneration changes
pros: the road has been hard and as staff eager for what the change was to bring. Must say it is not bad for started, i beleive better is coming
cons: this is not necessarily to mangement but fellow colleagues who theink they deserve the world when it comes to salry increases. They need to get a grip on themselves and work hard if they want to earn better and quit whining. The organization has brought us so far but they don't see that

review_title: Good place to build skills and get into sector. Poor working culture and senior management.
pros: A great chance to build skills, experiences and take on big responsibilities. Amazing to work on humanitarian crises and respond to emergencies occurring worldwide, and support fundraising events while developing workplace skills.
cons: Outdated fundraising model and increasing turnover in staff within that Department. Hopeless leadership at a senior level which leads to colleagues being overworked, worn to the bone and having their mental health affected by poor strategic decision making.

pros: Good cause and good people. A more comfortable work environment and culture than the overly bureaucratic BINGOs. Opportunities to travel. Good benefits (though not salary).
cons: The US headquarters is located lower Manhattan, but you make an NGO salary, so employment is just not sustainable for most in the long run. Unsurprisingly they have a high turnover rate. Recent restructuring has caused some issues and loss of moral but hopefully it will lead to future improvements.

pros: Creative Freedom and an friendly environment that enables me to push myself to be the best professional every day.
cons: As with many of us in the NGO sector, there are efforts to ensure stability in terms of job security but there is still some room for improvement in this area.

pros:
- Individuals that strike the right note find this an environment where they can thrive.
- There are bright spots that work quite well that underscore what the organisation is all about.
- Some of the leading lights have an acute level of self-awareness, if this is encouraged, it will be interesting to see what the future holds for the organisation.
cons: - The organisation operates in a changing environment and makes an effort to adapt. However, change management as a repertoire is still work in progress.

review_title: Great organization with a great mission
job_title: Capacity Building Officer in Washington, DC
pros: Great work, good people, two of the most flexible and supportive managers I've ever had, and by far the best benefits package I've ever had
cons: While competitive for the field, salaries can still be a bit low. Management is not necessarily good at communicating information about changes or potential changes to employees.

job_title: Field Coordinator in Juba, South Darfur
pros: The team are are like family, we born togerther very well
cons: Much activities are in hard to reach areas making it very challening if one is not prepare for it.

pros: Interesting job, where you can learn a lot and put into practice your studies, with the supervision and a good working environment.
cons: Salary. It is difficult to earn a lot of money working on the NGO's sector.

pros:
Committed colleagues. 
High job satisfaction as you are saving lives. 
Very interesting work and open to innovation.
cons:
Invoicing and paperwork is time consuming, each department needs more freedom and control over their finances. 
Lean, lean, lean! Every person has a few jobs...

job_title: Deputy Nutrition Program Manager in Juba, Baḩr al Jabal
pros: Action Against Hunger is dedicated serving to the most vulnerable beneficiaries (beneficiaries in hard to reach areas, e.g  Multi-sectoral team in South Sudan), quality/efficient program management and implementation, and commitment to staff capacity building.
cons: Action Against Hunger has less staff motivation in terms of social benefits.

pros:
They really value the person, treat them with respect, empower them, encourage creativity and give the opportunity to express ourselves, and this, for all positions in the organisation. 
Plus, at mission level we receive a great support from HQ: guidance, advice and support, not constraints and orders.
cons: The network between the other HQs is not strong in terms of pool for internal movements. Everything is informal.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: This US Chapter of the world-wide humanitarian organization ACF is truly humbling, and you really appreciate clean water, hot or cold, all the mod cons we have and how spoilt we are to live in the US.
cons: There is always some place in crisis, so there is always something to catch up on tomorrow.

pros: There is opportunity for growth with AAH as long as you have a good mentor/line manager
cons: The fact that AAH is fully dependant on Donor funding with very short grants it is impossible to work on staff retension, Improve the motivation of staff

pros: I was given unique opportunities to grow professionnally and personnally. I have had amazing experiences while working at ACF and the trust, professionalism and commitment of colleagues allowed me to find a profesionnal life balance for the first time in my life.
cons: Dealing with strong commitments and affects can be sometimes hard and social dialogue at ACF can be complicated.

review_title: Some growing pains, but a great organization
pros: I love the team that I work with. Everyone here really cares about the mission and work hard to achieve it. Great benefits.
cons: Some communication issues. Recent turnover and organizational restructure has lead to strain on staff.

review_title: Passionate people in the field who are demotivated by total apathy from top leadership
pros: Field offices are doing a great job
cons: Lack of vision and commitment from leadership . Many a times you feel .. they just don't care.

pros: As an intern at ACF-HQ, I had the ability to take control of my own projects, contribute new ideas and solutions, and receive advice on my career direction. A great organization to work for.
cons: Unpaid with transit and lunch reimbursements.

job_title: Program Manager (Field Coordinator) in Khairpur, Punjab
pros: learning environment,  employee receives Due respect, Career development
cons: need to work on capacity building component a broad

pros: There are no pros for this as there is not life insurance
cons:
There is not workmans compensation cover. If as a staff i died today on the job after working for the organisation for so many years, my dependents/next of kin will literally get nothin from AAH, just my months salary. Not encouraging
Need to consider life insurance for staff or the workman's compensations benefits package. It is a requirement by law under the WORK INJURY BENEFITS ACT (WIBA) Chapter 236

pros: Motivated passionate staff in the UK office. Excellent field programmes. Lots of opportunities to grow and progress if you have strong ideas.
cons: Too much strategising and not enough doing in the UK office. There is a mix of experience and total inexperience among managers which means inexperienced people are often making decisions.

review_title: One the few that really go for the needs
job_title: Program Manager in Cairo, Cairo Governorate
pros: A diverse combination of staff, with opportunities all over the world.
cons: The evaluation must be taken seriously so you can keep the professional staff and get rid of the amateurs

pros: A International Organization working in Pakistan at root level with great cause & goals.
cons: Need to more efficient in Visibility of Organization work for awareness in community .

job_title: Human Resources Officer in Cox's Bāzār, Chittagong
pros: Stability of job, compensation and benefits
cons: less training opportunity for support staffs, personal conflict

review_title: Ineffective senior management, hostile work environment
pros: Teams in the field are dedicated and driven. Opportunities to do innovative work, if you are friends with the right people.
cons: Incompetence at the top, hostile work environment, Board unable or unwilling to take action despite requests from staff. High turnover. Issues in the field linked to decisions by now senior leaders will be swept under the rug.

review_title: Great organisation with opportunities for growth

cons: The salary and benefits package is not competitive

pros: work environment is perfect for growth and management style is changing to be more inclusive.
cons: Compensation needs improvement so as to compete and retain staff.

cons: Have areas to improve in management

pros: Wide portfolio of activity but within a clear mandate around undernutrition. Still promoting quality over quantity. Strong humanitarian commitment. Improving in term of salary and retention.
cons: Can be somewhat messy. Limited in term of career management and support to formal learning.

pros: Great benefits and work life balance. Everyone believes in the work being done here. A lot of great collaborations and team work. Realistic expectations of on boarding and work load.
cons: Still working out a major organizational restructure, but that can be a positive.

pros: Good working condition and staff relationship, good environment for development.
